750 mL bottle. 2008 Vintage. Barrel No. 96. Poured into Duvel tulip. Best before: 10/08/13 (on bottom of bottle).

APPEARANCE:

Pours light copper with burnt orange and light caramel brown hues. Hazy. 

Head is 2 fingers, pillowy, light tan/khaki colored, and has relatively large bubbles. In fact, color of head and size of bubbles is like injera. Head retention mid length. 


AROMA: Vinous. Sour. Dark red fruit (pomegranate, cranberry, and some cherry). Subtle oak and vanilla bean. Apple cider. Faint sea aroma (ie, salty ocean and seaweed, etc.). Extremely faint chalkiness  much more subtle than most sours.  


TASTE: Tart. Dark red fruit (pomegranate, cranberry, and some cherry). Sour apples. Extremely faint oak. Light graininess on finish. Subtle dark grape juice characteristic in background. As warms up, element of vanilla (that also has faint taste of white chocolate) as well as faint wet stone-like earthiness emerges on palate. 


MOUTH FEEL: Lively carbonation. Only slightly dry - less than expected, which I found to be positive. 


OVERALL: Predominantly sour taste is nicely balanced with some light sweetness. Elegant. Perfect for a hot summer night. Drinks like a sparkling pomegranate juice with light alcohol; feels healthy to drink. Highly quaffable.  Unsure that the Vintage is worth the price premium over the readily available Grand Cru.

Nice red clear colour. Proper head. Smells basement and apples. Sour taste, quite much of acid. Complex aromas, but not pleasant. Not for beginners, and not my greatest favourite. This could go well with meat foods.

2008 vintage on tap @ In De Wildeman. Red-brown color, with beige head. Aromas of lactic acid, sour cherries, wood. Flavor is sour and somewhat sweet, well balanced. Carbonation causes this to be not too sticky. Bit dry finish. Sometimes I really do like sour beers.

Bottle.Pours dark amber with a beige head.Aroma is funky , berries, oak, malt and sourness.Flavor is sweet and sour with berries, funk and oak.Medium body, average carbonation.Very nice , I want moore.

first beer at the Beer Temple, Amsterdam .. .2007-barrel 230 .. wow, such a tasty beer, from the books .. . light tang, light cherry .. . it gets the ducks in a row .. . the death of a whale, is a good thing .. . amazing amazing stuff!!! .. . shoot the moon! .. . I wish i had a case of this amazing stuff, now to track down the 2008 version .. . Im On VACATION!!!
Rodenbach Vintage 2008. Red colored brew. Aroma has cherries, sourness. Mild sourness, cherries, tartness in the flavor.

Rodenbach Vintage 2008 
Skulle visa sig vara mycket trevlig. Herlig syrlighet, mycket kolsyra, ganska bärig smak lite diskreta fattoner. Underbar (tur jag har tre till på lagring).

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2014 Pours hazy brown with a beige head. Aroma of green apples, sour berries, light vinegar, dark dried fruits, wood and some sweetness in the background. Taste add some sweeter notes of caramel malts leading to a sweeter nice dry sweet/sour end.

2008 Vintage. Bottle from Systembolaget. Ive been lazy and meant to just drink and run. But, smelling it I couldnt.

The colour is browner and less red than the Grand Cru. Old, damp wood on the nose along with... fizzy candy!

In the mouth it is surprisingly tame. Probably less tart than Grand Cru and fairly sweet. Nothing cloying but still sweet. Mild, fairly full in the mouth with a hint of tartness which will come back from your stomach to haunt you.

Bottle. Vintage 2008. Rich fruity and slightly acidic aroma of black cherries, wood, mild sweet vinegar and raspberries. Medium-bodied with strong notes of acidic red berries, sweet black cherries and wood  Long aftertaste of wood, cherries, immature raspberries with hints of red plums.

2008 vintage, barrel no 96. Reddish brown with small tan head. Very nice sweet and sour aroma with some cherries and marzipan. Soft woody and vinous notes. A little vinegary. Taste is initially sweet and then turns dry, sour and tart towards the end and the aftertaste is sour. Round and smooth for a sour ale, lovely mouthfeel. Would love to try this with a red washed-rind cheese.
Bottled, 2008 vintage:Pours a redish brown colour with a dense, foamy head. Old cellar, oak and cherry stones on the nose. Tart flavour of sour cherries, oak barrels and winter apples. Delicious!

2/2/11. 2008 bottle. Muddy brown pour (sparkling red when held to the light) under a creamy tan head that fades fast. Sour vinegar aroma with a big hint of wood and cherry cough syrup. Moderately sour entry with big cherry flavor that leans towards too sweet and cloying, all with a slight dry woody finish. Not bad.

750 ml poured into a tulip glass with 2008 Vintage.  The aromas are sour and earthy like malt vinegar and cherries...which sound weird but is great.  The appearance is a dark reddish brown with a minimal light tan head the does not last, but leaves nice lacing.  Taste is sweet cherries and oak, with a cider vinegar finish that is very clean.  This a sour of the highest quality...the oak aging really gives another layer of depth to the standard sour.  Very good brew overall.

2008 draft at mission dolores. Smells of carmel. Cherries and toffee. Dark ruby red color with nice head. Taste is tart with a touch of sour and sweet. This is the standard for all sours. Dont taste much of difference between the other rodenbachs, but they are all good
On Tap at Maxs as 2008 vintage, wow this should make you a sour fan.  Cherries and dried fruits under the dominant and deep citrus flavors with a clean finish.

2007 Vintage.  While this might not be a pretty brew, it is outstanding in every other way.  A more mellow and smooth version of the Grand Crew but every thing that is and more.  Excellently balanced in very light sweetness is the wonderful sour that you just have to love about the Rodenbach brand.  I dont know if there is a more constantly enjoyable sour out there.  This was my first Vintage, but I will assuredly be back!
Pours a clear ruddy brown with a thin tan head. Full Nose of cherries, caramel malts. Smooth flavor with the same influences. 07 vintage.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2011 I had the vintage 2007 and 2008.
The 2008 in bottle aswell on tap!
The beer is taken from 1 ageing barrel.

Better than the classic blend!

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2012 At a tasting, thanks beerandbeyond,[2009 Vintage] pours deep red with a nice head, aroma is sourish with cherries, wood, leaves, wet and malt, flavor of vinegar, cherries, grapes, carbo, medium bodied, very nice 8/5/8/3/13[3.7]

At a tasting, many thanks DSG, [2007 Vintage] pours dirty brown with medium head, robust soury aroma of sour cherries with notes of dates, nutes and wood, flavor is dry and sour, with plum liquor, plum cake, sour cherries juice, vinous acids, warming alcohol and tender carbonation, medium to full body, excellent brew  8/3/8/4/14[3.7]

750ml bottle.2008 wintage.Pours a murky brownish red with a fizzy reddish white head.Nose is cherry and red wine.Taste is vibrant sour cherry with oaky layers as well.The finish on this beer is spectacular and long.This is a really nice sour with layers of flavor.

At a tasting, thhanks DSG, smallish head, murky reddish colour with light orange taints, aroma of raspberries, sour apples, wine vinegar and a touch of spice, flavour of berries with winey notes, lemon, sour apples and some prunes and sherry in the back, light sour aftertaste. Very good and quite complex.

Bottle at a tasting, thanks DSG: blackberry infused vinegar, rasins, caramel, sweet malt, very rich. vanilla in the aroma, in the flavor you get more granny smith apples, rasines, plums, great tartness naxt to the sweetness, great beer.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2012 Re-rate 5/17/12: Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks beerandbeyond. 2009 vintage. Clear deep red-amber color with a big beige head. Aroma of oak, cherries, a bit of vinegar, lactic notes, malt and some cobwebs. Sweet-sour flavor with some malt, cherries and other fruits, some oak, a bit of vinegar and a dry finish. Medium-bodied. 8/4/7/3/15=3.7

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks jbrus for trading me this bottle! 2007 vintage. Murky red brown. Aroma of oak, lactic acid, some barnyard, cherries and some malty notes. Sour and sweet flavor, somewhat funky, of malt, yogurt, fruits (berries, cherries) and wood. Medium-bodied. 7/4/8/3/15=3.7

A dark very hazy reddish brown. Almost no head. Aroma is black cherries. Flavor is a beautifully smooth sweet and sour cherry. A lot of tang to it. Almost some chocolatey notes too. Rich and delicious. Very nice beer.
Sammys bottle specially brought in. 2007 vintage oak aged. Lightly foggy look, great sour cherry flavor and aromas. Smooth feel, and showing some wonderful vanilla and spice.
0.75l - Nose is stone fruit, dark color, little head.  Flavor reminds me of a flat Dr Pepper: fading carbonation, lots of sweetness, vague hints of cherry.  Nice, but not for the price.

On tap @ Rattle N Hum.
Brown/ruby with a bit of haze and some off white head. Aroma is sour fruit with some cherry and raspberry, acetic. Taste is somewhat sour but not over the top, very smooth. More fruit on the palate. I cant say Ive tried too many sours, but this is definitely one of the best ones Ive had so far.

Deep orange garnet pour with a largess beige head. The nose is loaded with cherry- dark fruit follows close behind. Red wine vinegar complements the tart acidic dark fruit notes in a very pleasant way. Raspberry seed comes in near the back. The flavor is huge dark fruit- cherry, plum, raspberry , bubblegum, black cherry, vinous barrel notes, and vinous acetic acid. The palate is super creamy with high levels of effervescence, leaving a tart dry finish.

2008 vintage. Reddish chestnut colored pour with a vivacious off-white head. Aroma holds beautiful notes of red wine vinegar, acetic acid, cherry, plum, and raisin. Also beautiful hints of raspberry preserves and earthy tartness.  Superb nose to this Flemish red. Flavor holds fantastic black cherry, Big League Chew, acidic tannin, and more fruity and vinous notes. Mouthfeel is wondrously crisp and effervescent, with a medium to light body. Amazingly yummy.

Deep amber in color, off-white head.  Tart/sour edge...didnt take better notes unfortunately.

Notes: 08 Vintage at Kerstbier Festival 10

2008 Vintage barrel 96.  Deep red pour with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is tart fruit, some sweetness some balsamic notes.Flavor is sweet and sour.  Not overwhelming in either case, but a really really nice balance.  Some wood notes are present.  Really nice beer.

(Vintage 2008, draught at Kulminator) The beer poured dark brown and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had sourness, berries and malts. Palate was medium bodied and dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were sourness, berries, fruitiness, wood, mildly sweetness and low bitterness. Afertaste had sourness and berries. Pleasant sourness with woody and malty background made drinking this beer an enjoyment.

Bottle. Thanks to Harrisoni for letting me try this one. In the olden days I would have referred to this as, "...a beer wot as gawn orf".  Now days Id use more considered language like, sour, and sharp with hints of fruit. Perhaps Id call it refreshing or zingy. Makes no difference how I characterise it really because basically its malt vinegar. Drop a couple of small onions in it and Id suddenly see the point. As it is, all I see is a beer wot as gawn orf.

07 bottle. huge nose. pungent sweet and sour. cherries, raspberry, grapes, musk, and just an engulfing acidity. bright red with a patchy head and great lacing. amazing balance of sweet and sour. silky and thick.

2007 vintage; my belgian beer #1000, courtesy of fiulijn - hazy reddish-brown colour with a little amber foam; a fair aroma of wood, vinegar, cherries and cheese; sweet and acidic, medium- to full-bodied with a long aftertaste of wood, cherries and acetone; some residual sweetness

750 ml bottle from Bev4less. 2008 Vintage. Pours a slightly hazy roan brown color with a small beige head that recedes to a fine film. The aroma is tart with vinegar, cherries, cider and funk. The flavor displays medium sourness with cherries, grapes, pomegranates, bread and oak. The palate is medium and smooth with soft carbonation. Finishes long with lingering tart berries. Overall: Wow, just wow.
Clear orange brown pour with a light tan head.  Oaky cream and vanilla aroma.  Toasted malt, molasses.  Some sour fruit and grape.  Sweet fruity flavor.  Oaky and wine like.  Moderate tartness.

750ml bottle from K&L, enjoyed while sitting in a hot tub.  Barrel #230, which seems to have been a big barrel.  Clear deep ruby red in color with a lasting one-finger light tan head and good lacing.  The aroma is nice, big on the cherries with slight vinegar, oak, and wild notes.  The flavor has both some sweetness and some tartness.  Big cherry flavors, balsamic vinegar, oak, and other fruitiness.  Smooth and somewhat tingly on the mouthfeel with lively carbonation and a long finish.  Really liked this one overall.

Thanks to TT for sharing! Deep amber color with small beige head. Aroma is caramel malts, tart cherries, some tart fruits as well as mild alcohol. Flavor is fruits, some quite dry wooden notes, tartness as well as some mild alcoholic notes.

On tap at Capones. Very red, moderate cream head. Lightly acetic nose, malt and cinnamon with Lots of citrus and Brett. Flavor a lot of druthers, cherry with strong lemon and Brett, also faint bread crust and a sweet chocolate. Lemon lingers on the lips after the drying, sticky, lightly acetic finish. Nice, controlled Flemish red, like the balance and Brett presence.

(Bottled, 0.75l, 2008 vintage) Clear blood red color with a small, firm head. Tart and vinegary nose with dark cherries. Flavor of tart maltiness, cherry, vinegar, some sugar in the background. Quite full body, lowish CO2. Excellent and nicely balanced. 5287
Clear reddish brown of color with a foamy off white head. An aroma of candy, caramel, sour and cherries. A flavor of balsamico, sweets, caramel and sour.

Draft. Pours medium brown with a bit of a reddish hue, topped with a small off white head. Tart lactic aroma, with notes of wood and sour cherry. Lactic notes hit the palate first, then cherry and wood join in. It becomes a bit sweet for a while, before cherry and lactic acid take over again. Some green apple enters towards the finish.  Wood lingers. Not overly tart. Refreshing.

2008 vintage on tap at Pizza Paradiso, Dupont.  Pours a hazy, ruby, garnet amber with one ring of white head.  Nose is tart, sour, cherries, berry, light wood, light cheese.  Flavor is tart, sweet, light vanilla, some coconut, light vinegar.  Medium bodied, tart finish.

Bottle. Vintage 2007. Pours a slightly hazed but still mostly clear brown mahagony color with a light tan head. Nice sweet fruit like aroma of apples and pear mixed with some acetone, earthiness, and oak. Light mouthfeel with a good amount of carbonation. Slight tart/tangy/sour notes up front but nothing too overpowering. Ends pretty dry. The balance of sweetness and sour really makes this on the light side of sours but it also is waht makes this beer so enjoyable and an excellent gateway into even more sours. Good lace left on the glass after I finished it off.

#230 @Tampa Wkly Gathering @TampaPourhouse Thanks tampabrew-750ml bottle-pours a light tan head and dark amber color.  Aroma is sweet medium malt, fruit-cherry, wood.  Taste is tart fruit-cherry, wood.

Rodenbach vintage 2007. On tap at delirium cafe (also drank the 2008 vintage at Kulminator - review is based on the former)... Mostly opaque  
darker reddish cinnamon brown with a thin film of soapy white head...  
Cherry sweet and mild on the vinegar perpsective, light acetone...  
Semi-sweet and acidic on the back palate with a sweet black cherry  
presence that meshes with an apple cider vinegar. Sweetness keeps the  
acidity at bay. Nice active carbonation to round things out. Less  
acetone on the flair thankfully. Solid oude bruin.
7/4/8/4/16

I liked it.  Maybe I even loved it.  But it lacked the intensity and the complexity of its non-vintage siblings.  Maybe the 2007 is just a hair too old now?  I dont know... But at almost twice the price of the standard grand cru it is a bit insipid.  Yes, same oak tartness, same fresh strawberry sweetness, same malt and vinegar and it sounds great.  Dark copper pour, small head, all the right stuff.  But at twice the price, with a little less complexity, it was a disappointment.  Dinged it a point for the price.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2013 Opaque colour,with a reddish tinge,  white bubby head.  Fruity aromas, this is a flanders red that is clearly cherry and is balanced as a wine would be.  Very lacey sheets.  The carbonation i right there. Very drinkable.
2007 a rich treat.

9oz draft served in a tulip.  Pour is deep red with very little white head on top.  Nose is vinegar, raspberries, cherries, and a spritzy rock candy smell.  Taste is a very tart, spritzy version of the nose that ends with a sweet, less tart, cherry finish.  On the whole, Im not overly into sours, but this is one of the best Ive tried.
750 ml bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar, thanks very much!  Sickeningly sweet, lacks the true character of the Rodenbach of old.  Best skipped.

Kerstbierfestival 2009. Clear brown pour with a thin beige head. The aroma has sourness, vinegar, wood abd fruits. Solid, well-balanced flavor of wood, sourness, vinegar and fruits. Its near excellence, very interesting.

750mL. Poured a clear, deep amber with a fizzy white head. Aroma is red grapes, balsamic vinegar, malt vinegar, sour patch kids (fruit punch edition). Taste is overly sweetened in normal Rodenbach fashion, lots of apple cider vinegar, cherry juice box, boxed red wine, balsamic. Whatever Palm did to Rodenbach should never happen to anyone again.

Bottle.  Pours clear amber with a medium, fizzy beige head, medium retention with light lacing.  Aroma is average malt (caramel, toast, bread), light hops (spicy), and average esters (fruity) with notes of grape and wine.  Flavor is average malt (caramel, toast, bread), light hops (spicy), and average esters (fruity) with notes of grape and wine.  Medium body and carbonation, light warmth and creaminess with a dry but sweet finish.

Pours a clear deep mahogany with a stringy-lacing froth of off-white head.  Has a sweet sugary caramel malty nose with some light fruity esters and mild oak.  Starts with a mild oaky tartness and some sugary sweetness before a slightly drier semi-tart finish.  Has too much sugary character and not enough complexity.
Sweet, vinegary, typical Rodenbach, apple cider/malt vinegar. Typical artificially sweet rodenbach. Bleh.

bottle thanks to SHIG, pours deep ruby orange with a thin off white head.  Aroma is complex and rich.  Notes of apple and that flemish red, some oak and light vinegar.  Flavor is soft and subtle.  Apple skin, wild yeast, moldy wood all provide solid sour and earthy elements without being acidic and mouth puckering.  An excellent sipper!

Amber with off white head.  Aroma is fairly sour, horseblanket, background oak, caramel.  Taste is tart up from followed by a cherry sweetness- fairly simple, light complexities.  Reminds me a far amount to Supplication 001 from what I remember of it.

tasting from the bottle at the Decatur Beer Festival on 10/16/10.  orange pour with a 1/2" off white head.  acidic, light cherry oak nose.  big sweet tart body with layers of raspberry, strawberry and vinegar.  sour / sweet finish with more oak.

On tap at Capones. The aroma of sour tartness with light berry notes. The color is amber with a ruby hue. The flavor of sour smooth berries/cherries go down easy on the palate with no lip-puckering needed.

Vintage 2007 on tap at Capones

A-pours a cloudy murky orange with a tan dirty head.

S-notes of tart cherries, touch of acetic acid with a light alcohol spice.

T-the flavor has sweet and tart ripe cherries with a strong acidity and a good sour finish. fruity, acidic, and sour blended well together.

M-grainy palate, crisp dry finish with assertive carbonation.

D-this has a nice ripe sweetness that is balanced nicely with a strong acidic presence and nice sour puckering finish.  it is extremely easy to drink and very inviting albeit straight forward and simple.

BCTC.  Thanks to whoever brought this.   Been dying to try this.  Red with ring and lace.  Woody cherry tart aroma.  Sour cherry woody tart complex.  Nice soft palate.  Wish I had taken better notes because I remember this was freaking awesome.

Bottle at SBWF 2010 (Brewery International). It poured  a hazy mahogny liquid. Sour and fruity smell. Sweet, fruity and sour taste. Refreshing and thirst quenching. Very nice balance between sweetness and sourness.

Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival.  Hazy brownish amber, small airy head. Tatr vinegary oak and cherry aroma. Dry and well rounded, gently spritzy. Fresh with oak and vinegar, complex and intense. Lovely beer!

25/09/2010 - from tap @ Karakterbierfestival Bissegem  
Pours a clear copper red beer, off-white head, fine laced and adhesive. Smell is very sour, typical Rodenbach aroma, sour apple. MF is a little flat, but texture is nice with a crisp bite to it. Tastes freshly sour, sour apple with apple peal and some caramel lingering in the back. Aftertaste has lemon acidity. Not sure if I would be able to taste the difference with the 2007, but again a very nice beer. More of the same, so more for us to drink of it. Hurray!
Brown with a red note. Has a lasting head, off-white. Notes of acid, fruit, solvent, glue. Candis. Flavor is moderate acidic, light sweet. Real soft and melow. Dry texture. Drinkable.
acid,solvent,red/brown, clear, white foam, medium sourness, salty, medium body, oily feel, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish.nice beer.
Quite nice, but didnt quite reach my expectations for the price premium.  Red fruits and light vanilla notes.  Medium acidity - excellent balance, as Rodenbach is known for.

750 mL bottle from DYCSoccer17. Thanks a bunch. Slightly rosy orange color, very fine and dense head. Very complex aroma of cherries, orange peel, spice, and less intense than expected woodiness. Strangely bifurcated flavor; moderate tartness and light sweetness seemly highly compartmentalized. Lots of red fruits and this fantastic thread of herbal bitterness throughout, vague but steady woody notes. Light acidic burn at the finish and very light bitterness. Awesomely refreshing and drinkable yet complex and nuanced.

Pours deep reddish brown. Thin beige head. Aroma is very sweet and malty with dark fruit.notes almost a cider smell. Flavour is amazing. Great carbonation flavour is bold and fruity with strong sweet malts. Very sour as well makes.me puckker. Very malty and sour well balanced this is a fantstic brew. Very dry finish. Complex with a.wide variety of flavours that mingle perfectly. I am glad to be drinking this beer in its prime.

Bottle, thanks to tytoanderso. Pours red/amber, more reddish than amber, thin off-white head, little lacing. Nose is vinegar, cherries, funk, brett, lightly cheesy, quite sweaty. Flavours run to sweet cherries, along with a very acetic (this is definitely Rodenbach!) tartness, that perfectly balances the sweetness. Cherries, leather, funk, barrel, cheese, smells great, tastes vastly better. A pretty top-notch sour right here, finish leaves me flat, its almost ketchup-like.

Bottle. Pours a very deep mahogany with solid light tan coloured head. Good lacing as it falls away. Good looking beer. Big aromas of sour cherry, some vingar and citrus acidity and a little oak. Unmistakably Rodenbach. Great aroma. Flavours are  brilliant plenty. Equal parts acidity and sourness with some malt sweetness to balance. Plenty of vanilla near the end. Mouthfeel is on the full side. Great beer.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pours clar dark chestnut red with a small, creamy, off-white head. Aroma has strawberries, oak, barnyard, light vinoiusness, lactic, vanilla. Soft carbonation, great dry and elegant mouthfeel. Flavour is tart, caramel, red apples. Very elegant, light berries. Deliciously simple, deliciously complex. Wonderful sugary sweetness mixed in well.

750mL bottle purchased from the Davis Food Co-Op.  Aroma has nice hints of cherry, fruitiness, wood, and a little sour funk.  Amazingly quaffable and well balanced aroma.  Mildly hazy ruddy amber body with a nice off-white head present.  Starts tart with some acetic hints, but not overly acetic and puckering.  The middle has some tart cherries with a scant amount of sweet cherry notes as well.  Finishes a bit dry with lasting woodiness, oakiness and nice tartness.  This is absolutely amazing stuff.  Incredibly well-balanced and well crafted.  World class.

Bottle from daleharshman purchased from Holliday Wine Cellar. Poured a golden amber with beige head. Aroma is tart cherries, funk, vinegar, salt. Taste was tart cherry, oak, pungent currants. Overall very good.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2010 Red-brown pour with a small tan head. Malt vinegar aroma and flavor, some cherry,  caramel, and nuts. Obvious notes of oak throughout, but this one hasnt picked up much funk or dust. Plenty of sourness to balance out the malt. Sharp carbonation.

Reddish brown pour with a white head.  The aroma has a strong apple cider note with hints of damp oak and some caramel.  The flavor follows through with more apple cider vinegar, lots of wet oak and a sweet brown sugar note on the finish.  Pretty much the same as the Grand Cru but it seems just a bit more mellowed out.  Dry, medium body with moderate carbonation.

Bottle from Utobeer market stall. Deep red pour with a beige head. Raisins, strawberry jam, caramel, light fruit aromas. Caramel, plum pudding, ripe cherry flavours. Smooth. Hasnt quite got the sweet/sour vibe of the Grand Cru. I fear this has been sweetened up a little too much. Quite nice but not quite there.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2013 Nice sour ale, great effort of Palm to put some new schwung into the Oud-Vlaams bruin... Perfect balance between sweetness and sourness. Nice malty and slight caramel flavours. Lots of dried grapes / raisins as well.
Bottle. Pours an amber ruby color with a small off-white head. Has a sweetish tart slightly vinager aroma with some woody hints. Sweetish sour tart woody flavor. Has a dry woody sour tart finish.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2011 Pours deep reddish brown with off white head, aroma is nice funk, oak, vinous grape, and some sweet malt with a nice acidic note. Taste is sweet malt leading into some funk, tart, dark grapes, with a dry finish that is still tart.  Good brew, much better than the regular version.
Reddish brown with a low head. Sour aroma with notes of sour apple and citrus. The flavour is funky, but still both balanced and complex with nice oak notes and a refreshing taste.

75cl bottle, thanks Jordan.  Medium off-white head atop clear garnet body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, cherry, wood, some sour.  Taste is moderately sweet, sour cherry, wood.  Light-medium body, moderate acidity, lightly watery.

(bottle, 75cl) Hazy, reddish amber colour with a cream-coloured foamy head of medium size. Sweet and slightly acidic and dusty malty aroma with notes of leather, woody accents and vinegar. Sour and moderately sweet flavour, medium bodied with a mild carbonation. Vinegary malty and moderately vinous fruity taste with woody accents; dry-out effect towards the slightly sweet and acidic finish. Good but a tad too sweet. 29.VI.10

075L corked bottle, kindly shared by KnutAlbert.  A thin ashy blond head upon a glowing amber body.  Light sugary, vinous cherry aroma. Dryness too, tartness and a gentle note of wood and vanilla. Taste is a nice blend of rounded acidity and refined fruity-berry sweetness.  Mild oak notes, soft malts. Smooth and oily in the mouth.  Strong body. Vinous, light sour-tart fruit ending.  Elegeant and harmonious. Great stuff.

Deep amber ... brownish pour cloudy with tan head .... decent lacing ... aroma is strong oak, vanilla and sour cherries and light vinegar ..... taste of sour cherries and very tart a light vinegar taste that kind of tarnishes this for me oaky and vanilla as well .... a good sour ale
750 ml bottle a dark red brown colored beer with a beige head aroma fruits cherries grapes oak caramel and sourness taste cherries dark fruits oak caramel and sourness
Not a great beer at all, not terrible, I wouldnt buy it again. I was expecting substantially more. I really hated this beer, had it twice now, just way too much vinegar and tannins.

Medium offwhite head doesnt last. Deep red body. Sugary cherry and vinegary apple aroma. Sweet-sourish barnyard and cheesy cherry taste with cinnamon and vinegar notes. Velvety, smooth mouthfeel. Balanced and harmonic. Mid-bodied. Dryish almond drops and acidic apples aftertaste with vinegary cheesy cinnamon notes. Very, very nice. (0.75l bottle.)

Bottle 2007 Vintage.  Aroma has notes of cherry, lemon citrus, sour funk, wood, cobwebs and cheese .  Dark brown hue with an average sized off-white foamy head that mostly diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is sweet and sour and refreshing.  palate is full bodied with an average carbonation.  Nice clean finish.  Overall a spectacular brew that exceeded expectations.  Sweet with a great cherry and citrus lemon sour finish.  Outstanding!

Courtesy of HOPSHUNTER. It pours deep copper with tan head. The aroma is berry fruit and heading into tartness, ripe sweet cherries, more berry fruitiness and then Brett at the end of the draw. The taste is a mix of sweet candy like cherry along with tart like notes and then a modest level of sourness. It ends refreshing. This is a smooth tasty brew starting with sweet cherry richness and then ending refreshing.

Bottle: Hazy, reddish-amber coloured, medium-sized, persistent off-white head; woody-sourish nose (a touch of balsamic vinegar) with traces of artificial sweeteners; moderate sweet-sour flavour, medium bodied; gets drier in the woody, lacxtic finish. Good, but not great.....

Pours a somewhat clear orangish red with a light head. Nose is light apple and sour cherry and soft wood notes. Flavor is not full on sour. Light on the acetic content compared to other Rodenbachs this one is well balanced with sweet fruit notes and yet lingering lactic sourness. Well integrated if lacking any real standout qualities. A nice sour but not their best.

Sour cherry on the nose with spicy mild sweetness in the aroma as well.  Pours amber brown with a thin white head.  Sour raspberry with caramel malts, tart with a mild sweetness and hints of brown sugar.  The beer is funky with a dry finish.  Very very nice!

Bottle from Brussels, probably Beer Planet.
Red beer, fluffy head. Sour cherry aroma, quite mild. Pronounced fruity sourness. Some oaky character. Well balanced, very drinkable.

750ml Bottle. Clear reddish amber pour with a foamy light tan head that doesnt last too long. Spicy, lactic aroma has cherry, caramel, apple peel, lemon, milk and cinnamon notes. Flavour is fairly sour and spicier than the aroma, with notes of apple, pear, lemon and cherry notes standing out from the hints of caramel, brown sugar, milk and wood. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel with moderate carbonation and a lingering tart finish that hides some sweetness on the back palate. This is a great sour, perfectly balanced and easy to drink yet still with powerful sourness. One of the best examples of this style I have tried.
Bottled. Dark redbrown color, medium head. Aroma of cherries, some oak wood, malt and hint of hop. Nice sour taste, quite sweet, bit dry oakyness to it. Good stuff.

Foeder 230; Sampled June 2010
A vigorous pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a dense, long lasting, light amber tinged, tan colored head.  The beer is a deep plum color that shows a brilliantly clear, ruby red color when held up to the light.  The aroma reminds me of a tart, fruity red wine, at least from a distance as I visually inspect the beer.  A clean acetic acid note, without the sharp spiciness that sometimes accompanies this acid, is just about the dominant note here.  It is anchored by a fruitiness that reminds me of concentrated apples, cherries and the afore-mentioned red grapes (along with some berry-esque aromatics).  Oak aromatics add some woody aromatics, a spiciness to the finish (that is faintly reminiscent of a barrel aged spirit).  A long draft of the aroma yields some toasted malt aromas that reminds me of browned bread crust and whole grain crackers, this couples in the long finish with a bright, though soft cherry-like note.

Lightly sweet tasting up front and this sweetness remains through to the finish; the beer is perhaps a little sweeter than I was expecting, though it is not entirely unexpected.  The sourness is quite light for something designated as a special vintage (at least with the direction I would have gone if I was the brewer) and in fact doesnt wholly balance the sweetness.  While this is a bit sweet, it is definitely only lightly so in the grand scheme of things.  The sweetness, coupled with the light acetic notes, brings out some cherry-like fruitiness in the flavor as well as a general berry like character; when coupled with the oak it reminds me a little bit of a super-fruity red wine.  Speaking of oak, this is actually a lot lighter in the flavor than it is in the aroma, which also perhaps makes the light sweetness more noticeable.  The oak contributes light flavors of fresh cut planks, subtly peppery spiciness, perhaps a suggestion of vanillin as well as some tannic astringency and textural interest.  The body of this beer is light enough to be quaffable beyond what the 7% abv would suggest, but does have some viscous body to it.  As the beer warms a toasty malt character comes out towards the finish and there is also an underlying caramelized malt character that is a large part of the perceived sweetness.

My second pour of this sees me noticing a touch of musty funkiness in the aroma and perhaps a touch of ripe cheese character, but these are quite subtle and the flavor doesnt really change much (given that this is brilliantly clear down to the bottom of the bottle this isnt much of a surprise).

This is a touch more simplistic than I might prefer, but it is still a fantastically tasty beer that I am quite happy to be drinking a 750ml bottle of.  Very clean, perhaps a bit too "filtered", but still this is quite enjoyable; the filtering perhaps even adds to the refined effect that this beer achieves (even if I prefer a bit more rusticity).  The aroma promises a bit more than the flavor delivers, but in the end the intangibles bring this to a higher level than the individual components seem to warrant.

750ml of the bloody stuff. Most expensive bottle picked up on a recent trip to Belgium (knowing, deep down, having eyeballed the blurb and polished-turd presentation at some length, it would probably be shit, but curiosity got the better of me), popped only because its about the nearest thing left in my house to a session beer, so here goes.... . Lazily beading chestnut with a taut ivory drum of head. Arrestingly damp oaky aroma like youve just walked into a freshly vacated vat; added balsamic sprinkles, Feta cheese (on the turn), mildew, cobwebs, mouldy cooking apples. Nothing wrong so far, but when you taste it, the trouble begins. First off, why the sweetness? Standard Rodenbach is nothing like this sweet. Secondly, if youre going to put out a wincingly sweet beer, why further adulterate it with (what tastes to me) like artificial sweetener? That nagging, test-tube bittersweetness  is distracting, and doesnt belong in a Flemish sour, or any beer, for that matter. Yes, of course, there is some rhubarb, iron, groaning old vat and mouldy apple-bobbing interest to this, with the same unanticipated parting kiss of caramel, Weetabix and milk  I remember from Vin De Cereale, but by then the sweetness has already rendered the beer semi-drinkable.  
Im tempted to say dumbed-down, vertiginously overpriced mess of saccharine and exploitation targeted at the export market. So I just did.

750mL bottle, purchased at City Beer Store. Pours a deep maroon color, effervescent, fading to cola and gold at the edges; creamy, tiny-bubbled, off-white head with good retention and persistent lacing; attractive pour. Sweet-and-sour acetic nose, lots of balsamic vinegar, overripe fruits, and bright oak character; Ive never been a huge fan of this style of sour ale, but the lemony tartness and non-syrupy fruit core hold this together well enough; I can do acetobacter, but the sweet-and-sour nonsense is never something I really enjoy, and this isnt quite dried out enough. Medium-full body; lightly creamy texture, relaxed carbonation, medium-high acidity; pleasant amounts of citric tartness, acetic acid, and loads of sweet-and-sour notes; this actually seems more rounded and more oaky in the mouth than what I (vaguely, its been awhile) remember of Rodenbach and the Grand Cru, which at least benefit from a prominent fruitiness; this shows a great deal of leather, tobacco, and hints at much darker fruits at the core; the texture is a touch heavy, the sweet-and-sour without sufficient acidity and carbonation Ive never understood, and you can tell that a great deal of love and time went into making this beer; Id like to enjoy this beer more than I do, and I wish most other beers went through a tenth this much time and patience; without the acidity, lively carbonation, and citrus presence, this is just a sweet-and-sour Belgian balsamic vinegar beer to me. I think this might make me a bad person. Medium finish of sweet-and-sour notes, leather, and a lasting overripe cherry and red fruit character that outlasts everything here; lightly tart.

In short: A sweet mellow fruity sour ale.  Very good beer but this is no Rodenbach Grand Cru.
How: Bottle 750ml.  Tasting session with Montreal crew.
The look: Partly cloudy redish-amber body topped by a very small off-white head
In long: No need for description here, we all know and love the regular Rodenbach products.  This one has a body as thin as the regular Rodenbach.  Sourness level is in between regular Rodenbach and the Grand Cru.  Unlike the rich and complex Oak/cherry sourness of the Grand Cru this one is more simple vinegary.  Oak is a lot more discreet than in the Grand Cru.  Feels much sweeter than other Rodenbach products.  Lacks the cherries and tannins of the Grand Cru, here it is more sweetened dark grapes and other fruits.  A lot less tasty than Grand Cru.  If you expect a Rodenbach Grand Cru quality or something standout from this special Rodenbach release youre in for a major disappointment. -The caramel-butterscotch presence could be too much for some.
-Carbonation is more relaxed than I expected.
-Leather aromas are there as well.
-Wooden dryness is perceptible, but by no means dominating.

Bottles.

750ml from Holiday, Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Nose is slightly sweet, and funky.  Taste is sweet, slightly, vinegary, clearly less vinegary than the Grand Cru.  Glad to try this its not over the top but its pretty good.

Tasted 2010-01-19. Vintage 2007, barrel 230. Poured amber with beige head. Very rich notes of prunes, caramel, and cookies. Funky sourness in a very well rounded way. Way better than the cereale IMO. This one is on the spot, when it comes to flemish sours.

A Mes rate. Bottle at Chris Os Night of the Gaylords.Good but not as good as it should be. Artificial sweetness and a little thin on the palate. All caramel and no trousers basically. Slight stewed apple notes, milky and lactic and maybe just a little too sweet. I feel a little let down here. It should be amazing but it just isnt. I was hoping for the Rodenbach of years gone by. What I got was good but should be soooo much better. Sort it out Palm.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2011 750mL bottle shared by PilsnerPeter, thanks Pete. It pours a clear amber-brown color, filtering apparent with no sediment at all.  Aroma has a sourness but it comes off cheap.  Take some filtered cherry-Flanders sourness, mix it with alcohol, and some cleaning product and you get a cheap imitation of a Flanders sour.  Flavor is more of a cider-like sourness but again an empty flavor, one sided, filtered and cheap.  Pretty unimpressive, I would much rather drink any other Rodenbach product. 7/3/73/14.6th beer of blind tasting.  Appearance is copper/orange/amber mix, no head.  It is thick looking with medium clarity.  Aroma is an earthy-sweet-souresque, some light overly wild or off-putting brett (in hindsight feral/goats-oil), and sweetness covering it up.  Flavor starts with candy sweetness, which is nice.  Then sourness breaking through and wild character I get on the nose.  It is good but something is slightly off for my tastes.  7/3/8/3/15, Standing in the tasting: personal  tied for 4th, overall  3rd    Final ratings is a combination of the two.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Bottle:  Nose was very flemish red-like with heavy sweetness, balsamic, red table grapes, and a vanilla touch of oakiness.  Very strong though...and piercing with the vanilla notes growing deeper with time. Dark, gleaming red-raped amber beer, frothy yet thin light tan head.  Flavors are sweet, tart, and grape-like.  The oak is not too forward but lends a hint of vanilla to round out the sweetness. Finish is clean and tart hinting at grape skins.  I used to love flemish red styled ales, but now I find them excessively sweet as well as lacking complexity...were there some funk or stronger accents of the wood aging, it would have been better...but its just so sweet that I cant really even tell the difference between this or any other rodenbach or duchesse or all those like-tasting reds.

750ml bottle thanks to ShadesofGray. Beautiful red color, looks a lot like Rodenbach Grand Cru. It smells pretty damn good, sticky sweet, sour green apples. the taste is quite good as well, barrel 230 must be a winner. The taste has a sweetness as well as a lemony sourness that is only slightly present, a nice Flanders red,

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-15-2010 02:44:50

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2010 Bottle at Chriso Gaylord tasting 09.  Thanks to Mesandsim for this.  Vinegar sour aroma.  Good frit in mouth and it will develop as a beer in years to come.  Bit of syrupy furit.  Could do with being a bit more sour, but that will come with age. 3.2/5  75cl bottle at Brew Wharf.  Lovely fruit, really dirnkable, thanks to Tom for this one. 748414 3.7/5.0  Re-rate bottle at Struise School.  Its official.  I now love this beer.  So drinkable as to be untrue.  Not the most complex, but it has a straightforward drinkability the like of which comes with very few beers.  Enough character for appreciation, good fruit and some sourness.  Wonderful.

Dark amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is woody and slightly sour berries, acidic candy-like fruit, vanilla and caramell. Flavour is rather big, round and smooth with notes of vanilla, oak and caramell. Ends on a slightly acidic note wood berry fruit and wet wood. Mouthfeel is smooth, body is larger than expected. Very drinkable.
From a bottle poured a dark ruby color with a fair amount of head.  Nice tart flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

Bottle. 

Pours a pale amber with a small of white head. Some lacings.

The aroma is somewhat acidic with notes of caramel, wet wood, oak barrel, vinegar.

The taste is mildly sweet and tart with prominent candy-like notes of caramel. Notes of tart fruits, vinegar and oak barrel. Quite full in flavor. A mild character of dusty cellar. The finish fairly clean with a light tartness to it, hints of alcohol and wood.

Medium body with a fairly smooth texture. Reminiscent of a smoother and rounder Rodenbach Grand Cru.

Good one, but not spectacular. Too similar to the Grand Cru to justify the hefty price tag.

750ml Bottle:  Sweet, vinous aroma of cherries, light wood, and a hint of funk.  Poured orange/copper/amber in color with a small, tan head that disappeared quickly.  On the second pour, the dead was creamy, and did not disappear.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Flavor is medium to heavily sweet and medium tart.  Tastes of cherries, light funk, light wood, and a slight hint of alcohol.  Medium body.  Medium body.  Tingly texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Tart cherry, slight wood, and slight funk finish.

Bottle shared at puzzls New Years Eve 2009: Pours a rusty amber with a light tan film of head. Lots of acetic character in the nose- some passion fruit, mild cherry and oak as well. Crisp body. The flavor has lots of cherry and acetic passion fruit character. It definitely falls short of their readily accessible Grand Cru in terms of rich balance between tart fruits and acetic character. Its still nice, but I expected more.

Deep amber colour with small beige head. Aroma is caramel malts, tart cherries, some tart fruits as well as mild alcohol. Flavour is fruits, some quite dry wooden notes, tartness as well as some mild alcoholic notes. Very pleasant. Rating completed at sayravai tasting November 2010.

Bottle at Theis og Mette.
Clear orange brown coloured with a small off white head.
Sweet aroma of caramel, glue, red wine and wood.
Fruity flavour of caramel, red wine, wood and glue with acidic notes.
Tart finish.

From the christmas tasting. Thx for pulling these bottles on the table M. The bottle says that this comes from barrel nr. 230. 
The pour is a redish brown with a tanned head that slowly disappeares. The aroma remindes me of young strawberries - sweet and sour at the same times. all together presents a clear Rodenbach profile.The taste is also nicely balanced between sweet and sour notes. It has clearly notes of wood, some honey and chestnuts. The finish is nicely mild and sour. Nice creamy palate

Pours a very dark amber color with a nice quarter inch white head. I let it sit a little while to warm up. After the wait, the first sip reveals an explosion of taste and complexity. It starts off with similarities of a Belgium Quad but quickly gives way to the sour acidity that is typical of this beer style. Each sip is like cleansing the pallet with sorbet. The acidity makes your mouth water and want more. It is an excellent beer that is masterfully crafted and  balanced between sweet and sour. One of ,if not the best sour ale I have ever had. If you find it, buy it and please let it sit a while to warm up. Awesome sour ale.

75cl bottle @ Vinens Verden, Odense. Pours cloudy amber color with a reddish hew and a small creamy white head. Nose is berries, balsamic vinegar, a bit of almond and sweet caramel. Smooth palate. Flavor has a good and tart freshness. Seems quite young - still.

Bottled. Really weird cork on this one, extremely short. Broad, acedic acid aroma, cherry, hay, vinegar. Warm, mellow, inviting flavor, with a mildly sweet acidity and light cherry balance. Very reminiscent of the original Rodenbach. Not overly sour or complex, nor is it overly impressive. A decent sour beer and nothing more. I know Rodenbach can do better, I just wish they would.

Reddish brown color with a live white head that disappears quickly.  Aroma of dark fruit, vinegar, and oak.  Flavor of dark fruit, some oak, and vingar. Very nice, but lacks that tart zing so common in sour ales.
Bottle. Aroma big on dried fruit and oak along with the expected bugginess. Flavor again centers around dark, dried fruit with maybe even touches of brown sugar. Tart but not overly so. Pretty good.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2015 Bottle at Sunes - Thanks to Hippie-Jesper. Clear red/brown - offwhite head. Leather, oakey, vinegar, red berries, balsamic, rubber, brown sugar, coconut -> wooden notes, nice carbonation. Lovely dryness.....ReRate: Rodenbach - Vintage 2013 Foeder 149. Bottle at home - Bottle share. Clear brown - white head. Spicy. Medium sourness. Wooden. Red berries. Light vinegar. Lacto. Tannins. Light medicine. Nice.

Bottle.  Pours a clear brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma of sour cereal grains, sweet tart candies.  Flavor is quite tart initially with the sour grainy malt in the finish.  Some sweet apple notes too.  Quite similar to regular Rodenbach Grand Cru if I remember correctly...nonetheless, it is quite enjoyable.
8/4/8/4/15 [3.9/5]

A dark red/brown colored beer with a beige head. The aroma is some sour with wood. There is vanilla. The taste is sour with wood. Notes of fruits with makes it a little sweet. The aftertaste is sweet with mostly sour and a little bitter.

From bottle at 15e Kerstbierfestival, Essen. Red brown with a small tan head. Sharp berries and yoghurt aroma, very vinous. Sharp acid attack, milky sourness, berries. Then some sweetness, still not for the faint-hearted. Good carbonation. Great stuff.
ambrato carico poca schiuma poco persitente il naso e acetico lattico mela un po di speziatura in bocca ancora acidità legno piuttosto secca
dark amber coloured body with a off white head a soury fruity aroma a soury fruity sweet taste with a soury bitter finish
Light brown coloured beer with a small off-white head an no carbonation. Sour aroma. Full palate. Finish is sour. Nicely balanced beer, good one.

Bottle. High creamy and long lasting white head. Clear copper body.  Lemon grapefruit vinegar acidic to sour aroma with notes of dried fruit. Relatively mild and sweet fruity flavor with some acidity but not really sour. Low carbonation, long aftertaste.
UPDATED: SEP 4, 2014 38cl, Vintage 2012, exclusive brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex sour brew, balanced, clear, small head, very good brew

Clear amber with a medium beige head. Aroma had plenty of lacto, sour berries, toasted malt and wood. Sour flavour with lacto, toasted malt, wood and sour berries. Finished sour. Very drinkable and a nice session flemish red.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of Ungstrup. Pours a deep reddish amber with a tiny off-white head. Tart woody nose with notes of cherries and marzipan. Medium body, very tart yet with an underlying sweetness and again elegant woody edges. Tart finish. A delicious beer yet not really with enough complexity to be a world classic. 141109

Bottle, 7.0%. Mild but good citric aroma, quite lactic. Hazy red brown colour. Very small tan head. The flavour is nicely citric, lactic again, raisiny. But not extreme, quite well-balanced. The finish has more lactic acid, dries out a bit, but is still sweetish.

75 cL bottle. Pours cloudy dark orange with a huge and light tan head. Aroma is fruity, light acetone and sweetish. Sweet malty and mild citric flavoured. Slight phenolic and dry malty with milky base flavoured. Somewhat sweet into the finish, yet with a growing acetone dryness and bite. Dry and acetone lasting impression once the initial sweetness has declined.

Bottle. Pours beautifully deep reddish brown/chestnut coloured with a small bubbly lasting off white head. Aromas of raspberries, dairy, caramel, balsamic vinegar and wood. Smooth flavour with notes of tart wood, sweet sugar, sour berries and spices. Great beer!

750ml bought at Vinens Verden Odense. Hazy deep red with  lasting off-white head, sort of creamy. Red wine dominates the aroma, with wonderful vineous oak and raspberry notes, lacto, and definite diacetyl. Smmooooottthhh flavour, with wood, berry, tartness and sweetness and extreme deliciousness. Over a couple of years, this may very well turn out to be not just a superior Rodenbach but  a plain masterpiece

2 years on foeder n°230..guess not all foeders are alike..i like foeder n°132(Vin de Céréale) more. Still a very good beer, very smooth, soft balance between sweet n sour. "The Vin" is more outspoken and has more punch to it ;-)
Hereby i wish to place another order for some Vin dC please! Maybe next year?

2008 version, draught Very good light-beige, dense and fine head over red-amber-shot brown beer, clear. Nice Rodenbach nose with lactic & little acetic acid; fruity, woody.  2009 version, bottledHuge foxy-cream coloured head over foxy red-amber beer. Sharp-sourish, really acetic nose. Fruit following, cherry liqueur. Cherry-filled chocolates to finish. Sourish, tart, woody and fruity, with some restsweetness for excellent balance. Sharpish, acidburn, quite well-carbonated, luxurious texture. Very good Rodenbach, concentrated on fruit and tart wood.
